body.name: The Last Sinner: A Chilling Thriller with a Shocking Twist (A Bentz/Montoya Novel)
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews Review Praise for The Last Sinner“Is the potential return of a series villain the end for a clever detective and his daughter, a true-crime author, in the last book in Jackson’s Rick Bentz and Reuben Montoya series?...Excitement for series fans looking to revisit Bentz and Montoya’s greatest hits while promising something new for the future.” —Kirkus ReviewPraise for Lisa Jackson’s New Orleans Series: “Immediate and visceral, Jackson’s latest is a superlative beach book, guaranteed to keep you glued to your folding chair until the sunlight fades. Especially gripping are Zoe and Chloe’s struggle to survive their ordeal, which takes the narrative in surprising directions...Jackson definitely knows how to keep readers riveted.” —Mystery Scene on Never Die Alone “Terrifying...a creepy thriller sure to please Jackson's many fans.” —Publishers Weekly on Devious “A nail-biting tale of dangerous secrets and deadly passions...should prove irresistible to fans of gritty, graphic suspense.” —Booklist on Devious “Filled with twists and secrets at every turn." —The San Gabriel Valley Tribune on Devious “Explosively riveting… a stunning success.” —The Providence Journal on Devious “Tense…suspenseful…shocking…will leave readers on the edge of their seats.” —Booklist on Absolute Fear “If you love to be scared or you crave a good heart-thumping thriller, look for this one. Shiver is going to make you shudder.” —The Delaware Gazette on Shiver Book Description A Chilling Thriller with a Shocking Twist About the Author Lisa Jackson is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of over ninety-five novels, including Liar, Liar, You Will Pay, After She's Gone, Deserves to Die, Running Scared, and Shiver. She is also the co-author of One Last Breath, Last Girl Standing and the Colony Series, written with her sister and bestselling author Nancy Bush, as well as the collaborative novels Sinister and Ominous, written with Nancy Bush and Rosalind Noonan. There are over thirty million copies of her novels in print and her writing has been translated into twenty languages. She lives with her family and beloved dogs in the Pacific Northwest. Readers can visit her online at LisaJackson.com. Read more

body.description: The #1 New York Times bestselling author of The Girl Who Survived delivers a gripping novel of suspense featuring two veteran homicide detectives matching wits with a twisted serial killer lurking in the shadows of New Orleans.There are killers so savage, so twisted, that they leave a mark not just on their victims, but on everyone who crosses their path. For Detectives Bentz and Montoya, Father John, a fake priest who used the sharpened beads of a rosary to strangle sex workers, is one such monster.Bentz thought he’d ended that horror years ago when he killed Father John deep in the swamp. But now there are chilling signs he may have been wrong. A new victim has surfaced, her ruined body staged in deliberate, unmistakable detail. Either it’s a terrifying copycat, or Father John, the detective’s own recurring nightmare, has come back to haunt New Orleans.Another death, and another. Bentz is growing convinced that Father John isn’t just back. He’s circling closer, targeting those Bentz loves most.And this time, he won’t be stopped until the last sinner has paid the ultimate price…“Jackson definitely knows how to keep readers riveted.” —Mystery Scene Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Ms. Jackson never disappoints
reviews.reviewText: I never grow tired of Bentz and Montoya. They are so different, but dedicated to NOPD. Their investigations may be a little unorthodox but they get the job done. I like the way past characters are woven into the crimes. It’s nice to revisit them and their stories. This time we get to go on the climax of a psychopath who has plagued New Orleans for decades. He was almost apprehended several years ago when Rick shot him and thought he was dead. But life is stranger than fiction. When his signature turns up in a murder, he knows the truth is about to get very complicated. There are so many people to investigate. So many reasons why. Excellent read. Get a cup of coffee and settle in with this book. You can read this series in order or they stand alone.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book is full of violence and murder. Different situations collide and blend together, suspense grows, and resolutions develop at the end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars The shocking twist is...these stories never end.
reviews.reviewText: I feel like I've had my rights violated, been through double jeopardy, along with several recurring characters in the Bentz/Montoya universe. It's not enough to fight for your life once in these books. Nope, every day is a new opportunity to put yourself in harm's way, do business with people who arguably are as psychopathic as the serial killers they long for their writers to write about and argue with, and assert your independence if it kills you. Please, please, PLEASE can we retire the trope of the woman claiming "if I live in fear he wins"? There's living in fear and there's not being a moron, accepting a little protection when a killer is most certainly after you. There's got to be a way to make intelligent female characters a little more intelligent when it comes to survival and still move thrillers along. It's 2023. The characters have read those books. Anyway, this one was difficult to read because it was cruel to characters we're attached to, it teased the next book (I think) and a couple other potential problems that we now know can be enormous in the future, and it left Montoya looking kind of mean.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I just love this series!! Such great reads, and the twists get you every time!Very dark and moody, this book finally tells us what happened to Father John.I'm hoping by the way it ended there will be another one? Fingers crossed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good read, but I feel like I missed something
reviews.reviewText: I have read Lisa Jackson for a long time. I have read every book in this series, and I love both Bentz and Montoya. Having said that, I felt like there was almost too many things going on in this book. Since reading the last story, I had wondered about Cruz Montoya and where his story was going. But here you have Kristi being attacked and her husband winding up dead. Father John back again doing the same old, same old. And, yes, Cruz was part of the story, but still no real meat if you know what I mean. He needs an actual story, and it does seem like it is leading there, but how many books does it take to get there? And, is it too much to ask for the next book to focus on one story? I think that's why I feel like I missed something here - for example, Cruz showing up at the Cooke residence when Kristi was having a showdown with her husband's killer? I don't feel like there was a logical explanation for that. He was at her house, and ran from his brother and just happened to run right to the Cooke place? That didn't gel for me.So only 4 stars for me. Next time, one book, one story, please. :)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 6, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I'm at 33% and not enjoying this. I've read loads by author including others in series, some years ago. So despite this, I was confused who what are the characters. Loads of typos and contradictions that make this very wearing and tiring to try and read. I gave up on author a few years ago because quality of her books diminished drastically. Unfortunately this book does nothing to alleviate those perspectives. I just think this whole book is a shambles. Maybe that's why it's reduced to 99p.Eventually finished this but to be honest, skip read loads and even then found more typos, inconsistencies, contradictions. Then the ultimate pet peeve, it ends in a cliffhanger. This is a very muddled book that needed serious editing before being released to paying public.
Always good story and it’s a continuation of a series and I likethem
